prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Limitations on Panel's power—Transfer for pretrial proceedings only

para.paratext: Since its inception, the Panel's powers have been limited to transfer of actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. The Panel has never had the power to transfer actions for trial purposes.

When 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 was adopted in 1968, there is little doubt that Congress (and the courts) intended that transfer be made for coordinated pretrial proceedings, and that actions would be remanded to the districts where they had by initially filed. Remand would occur unless the case were settled or decided by the transferee court on motion. The Panel began its existence practicing in this manner, remanding cases that were not settled or decided on motion in the transferee court.

Despite the presumption that transferred cases would be remanded to the districts where initially filed, in practice the vast majority of cases were not remanded. Many are, and were always intended to be, resolved in the transferee court. In addition to resolution by dispositive motion or settlement, methods clearly appropriate under the statute, however, courts began to recognize the power to transfer cases to themselves under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) for all purposes. Indeed, courts began consistently to recognize the power to transfer cases to the transferee court under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) for all purposes.[1] The self-transfer practice became, as a matter of practice, nearly a presumption, and the Panel even enshrined it in its own rules.[2] The Panel also ruled in 1972 that it would not even entertain a motion for remand while a self-transfer motion is pending in the transferee court.[3]

In 1998 self-transfer came to a halt, more or less. The Supreme Court decided in Lexecon, Inc. v. Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach,[4] that self-transfer is not allowed under the statute creating the Panel. In Lexecon, the district court ordered transfer to itself for trial rather than remand to the district where it had been filed, and the Ninth Circuit denied review by mandamus,[5] and affirmed the self-transfer on an ultimate appeal.[6] Judge Kozinski's dissents in the two decisions are strong, lucid, and ultimately foreshadow the essentially unanimous Supreme Court decision (Justice Scalia did not join in part of the opinion, although he did not write separately).

The Supreme Court also determined that although no power of “self-transfer” exists under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a), the parties may presumably consent to transfer of the actions to the transferee judge for trial. Courts have recognized that authority even before Lexecon was decided.[7]

One possible alternative means of transfer is transfer of the cases by the transferor court, after remand, back to the MDL transferee court. This approach is probably fine if the criteria for 1404(a) transfer are met without regard to expertise gained by the transferee court during the MDL proceedings (and assuming that the actions could have been filed in the MDL transferee court in the first place).
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
